docs.lead_paragraph: Four out of five middle-aged American men run the risk of dying prematurely from heart disease because of unhealthy levels of cholesterol in the blood, Government scientists reported today. The research, based on a study of more than 350,000 men, found that even moderate levels of blood cholesterol increased the odds of death from heart disease and that the danger was present even in men who did not smoke or have high blood pressure. ''I think the numbers speak rather clearly for themselves,'' Dr. Jeremiah Stamler, a cardiologist from Northwestern University, said. ''The optimal level is 180, and 80 percent of this population is over 180.

headline.main: JERSEY SEEKS TIGHTER CURBS ON SMOKING

byline.original: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: Officials in New Jersey, where some of the nation's toughest curbs on smoking are already in effect, are seeking new ways of discouraging the use of tobacco products, especially among children and teen-agers. A bill will soon be introduced in the Legislature to raise the legal age for buying tobacco products to 18 from 16, the Speaker of the State Assembly said. The Speaker, Charles L. Hardwick, Republican of Westfield, said the bill would also raise the fine for selling tobacco to those under the legal age to $250 from $100.
